keywords.value: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
keywords.name: organizations

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Jonathan Soble from Tokyo; Silvia Taulés from Barcelona, Spain; Keith Bradsher from Pune, India; and Jonathan Weisman from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The fatal Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia last week highlights a lesson already learned by many other nations: You get what you pay for.

headline.print_headline: Low U.S. Rail Spending Hurts Safety, Experts Say
headline.main: Low U.S. Rail Spending Leads to Poor Safety, Experts Say

snippet: The fatal Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia last week highlights a lesson already learned by many other nations: You get what you pay for.
abstract: Global rail travel outside of North America is faster, with trains sometimes traveling at speeds exceeding 200 miles an hour, yet accident rates so low industry rivals safest airlines; aftermath of Amtrak wreck outside Philadelphia, when train was traveling half that speed, brings to light how little money United States invests in its rail lines as compared with other developed countries.
